title: The Sion Int Strat is Anti Fun
body: Like I don't know how to explain it any more that that it's just so annoying to play against, even Teemo takes more brain power than this. Both times going up against this I was unfortunately playing a tank at least if I was playing a carry champ I would get fed off him inting but since I was a tank me being fed doesn't really matter especially if I have to sit top and stop him from brainlessly pushing or he will litterally end the game since hes sion his demolish damage is equal to fucking rift herald lol. I'm sorry I hate complaining but this shit is just lame.

replies.body: Sounds like playing vs tryndamere.

Except Sion pushes the turrets faster ironically enough..

Or at this point it isnt even ironic. Ap trynd pushed better than AD trynd lol.

Can you fill me in on how this "Int. Sion" works?
I've got 200k on the Champion & I've never heard of a strategy where Sion just intentionally feeds to win.


The Strategies/Playstyles I play are;
- AP Sion mid 
- Full HP/Smite Mid (Uses demolish, but you don't have to feed to make it work)
- Full AD Sion top
- Glacial Augment Support (Righteous Glory Rush)
- Comet Support/Top (in the event it's a poke lane)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N08sUOWBaVk

Put the speed up to x2

So it's basically the Full HP/Smite Mid strategy, except there's no Smite involved & it's Toplane as opposed to mid.
------------------
You don't have to feed to make that work. All you need is to farm up minions for your [W: Soul Furnace] passive. Play safely & farm up as Sion can use a Fully charged Q & W explosion to farm up waves. Also make sure to Ward your blind spots as Sion has no real mobility, which would result in you being easy pickings for the enemy team. Sion's Engage/Roaming tool, [R: Unstoppable Onslaught], can also be used as an escape tool if you find yourself caught out. At roughly 30%-40% CDR at Rank 3, Sion's ultimate has a cooldown between 36-48 seconds. 
----------------
Sion has very little mobility outside his ultimate & since he's reliant on farm to make this strategy work, you could bully him & try zoning him from his waves. Treat him as you would Nasus (or even Toplane Heimerdinger), shut him down & finish the game before he scales. Also keep in mind that Sion can do ALOT in teamfghts, knocking people up & Shredding/slowing people with his [E: Roar of the Slayer].
---------------
Now as for Sion "Inting", that's on the player, not the champion. Sure, Sion is really good & as matter of fact is considered one of the best tanks in the game. However there shouldn't be any justifiable reason to feed in people's games.
It's "inting" because you literally only go for tower/inhib; never group, you force the enemy to respond to you through persistence to the point of inting.

That's split pushing in a nutshell, but I do understand why it's good (Synergy with Demolish, Grasp of the Undying & Sion's W Passive). Just saying that feeding kills in order to get objectives seems unnecessary to me is all.

Also, sorry about that wall of text. I kinda got carried away.

The issue is that it creates an unhealthy pattern. I have won as it and against it. I went 1/16 with some of the most tower damage in the game, and lost to one who went 3/19. You just first by Zz'Rot and auto push maxing Q. The second they back you drop portal with minions or tank it yourself and you just destroy towers. At one point with no minions at all and nearly full tank I took a tower from 100 to 40% with just portal and passive. Split pushing is one thing but Sion literally only needs to proc demolish to out push you compared to someone like Trynd or Shyvana who has to try and force you off the objective.

The difference between this and splitpushing, is that you can respond to a split push, and prevent them from taking your tower.

All sion needs to do is ult into your tower, demolish, and then keep autoing it, with a zzrot helping.

Yes & no, it is very similar to split pushing, but split pushers will TP to their team in the event of a team fight / baron fight. They also will back away from being collapsed on, inting Sion does not do those things.

thats how splitpush works though, you draw the attention of the enemie team towards you by threatening their base, so they either respnd and the rest of you're team has an oppening to take some onjective, or they don't and you eventually grind down their base. Annoying as fuck but not exactly inting or a sion only issue.

Wait... that’s not actually inting.  The guy is generally playing to win, and he’s not taking any unnecessary risks.  While it’s not something Riot would be happy about, it’s not exactly ban-worthy either.
What if taking a tower/inhib resets gold value?

> [{quoted}](name=i cant move wtf,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=9OcGX1Z5,comment-id=0009,timestamp=2018-10-06T08:31:47.313+0000)

very interesting idea not sure how that will play out though but by no means not a bad thought what so ever

I am guessing that he just gets to tower and keeps attacking it even if he is killed and destroying theses towers with Demolish. I am not familiar with the strategy as I have not seen it at least in high plat ELO. The way to counter this is simple, but you may need team help depending on the scenario. 1 pick a good split pusher that will keep you top all game (trydamere, shyvana, Jax, or others) you can push it down and Sion cannot duel them due to them doing so much damage. 2 ward heavy and kill him before he reaches your tower (by yourself if you can or with your team), 3 just go 5 v 4 the enemy team and win, 4 ZZrot portal can help keep pressure in the lane.

Shyvana and Tryndamere have more staying power since they are manaless, but yeah.  Someone who can run circles around him, outshove him, and shred him is the way to go.  Yi would work if his movespeed weren't tied to his ult.  Shyvana is probably better than Tryndamere as she has %hp damage and can contribute more to fights when he is down and she can roam, but then again I'm biased :)

Oh, and Shyvana can shove freely with no items.  Tryndamere needs Tiamat, Shiv, or AP.

it's not because it's impossible to deal with because it's not it's just very VERY anti fun to deal with all together it's like tending to a stubborn child lol and I can't always counter pick it I'm normally a team player and pick what the team needs and most of the time team needs a tank so I pick tank

Split pushing has always been hard to deal with / anti fun for everyone who's NOT the split pusher.

Trynd, Yorrick, and a couple of other top laners (most of whom aren't viable right now) do this exact same strat. 

In the past Nid, Trundle, Renekton, Rengar, and others have abused this exact pattern.

They don't come "back from the dead" line Sion does, but generally trade that for a LOT more dueling power. So Sion's unique in that he's able to do this as a tank, which doesn't actually add much strength because a BIG danger with historical problem split pushers is how they're all too capable of murdering one (or even two) people sent to stop them. So that's a trade off which is fair.

yeah but theres somthing worse about this one the reason they split push is because they can 1v1 really well Sion just takes really long to kill lol

> [{quoted}](name=BrightWîngs,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=9OcGX1Z5,comment-id=0002000100000000,timestamp=2018-10-06T08:07:19.507+0000)
>
> yeah but theres somthing worse about this one the reason they split push is because they can 1v1 really well Sion just takes really long to kill lol

Which is, again, not a problem.

Historical 'problem' split pushers have been monsters which absolutely no one can out duel (Nasus, Trynd, Nid, Trundle, Jax, ect) and are quite capable of turning 2v1s if they're fed enough.

They've also tended to, again historically, have an easy time escaping unfavorable situations. Shortly after release Rengar emerged as a split pushing power-house, and his stealth was powerfully nerfed as a result. Trynd, Nid, Jax, and a few other "split-pushing duelist escape artists." have had nerfs for the same reason over the years.

Sion isn't that. He's sort of semi dangerous early and mid game if you don't know how to play against him / aren't playing the right champs, but his kill potential is mostly up to his enemy to fumble. His ulti can get him out of sticky situations, but it's also hard-countered by simply being ontop of him or walking infront of him. It's not like Nid out-running entire teams via bushes and jumping walls.

So Sion is worse in almost every way than historical problem split pushers. Like, non-viably worse. As in he'd be garbage at it, or at least should be.

His only redeeming quality is how much health he gets. This lets him double dip; it makes him hard to kill, and makes him dangerous to towers via the Demolisher rune.

But even still, 'hard to kill' isn't a huge problem. He's not going to win any 1v2s ala previous problem split pushers, nor is he good from escaping this self-same fights. He's wholly unique in that he's a tank who can split push effectively (I guess, technically, Singed qualifies too?), but he's MASSIVELY easier to counter than others have been in the past.

Seen it, looks unhealthy. I hope i won't encounter it.
However, if you lose against it, you'll still have the right to report him for "inting".
For all i know, that strategy may be effective, but at a great cost of a 2 week ban or even perma-ban for inting.

So consider this, you lose to this strategy, just report him and once you get a response about your report, that's you saying that player using the int strat: "this is what you get for playing an effective yet unhealthy strategy!"

That is... _not_ how reporting works actually. And you will devalue your reports doing this.
Your reports dont get devalued anymore afaik with the automated system now in place.
I mean, you could report, but it wouldnt do anything. And even if the system did ban him for i ting, riot manual review would override it. Its not reportable, nor is it "cheating".

I disagree with branding it as inting. I remember a debacle a while ago where a full tank team won in Ascension _by_ dying consistently. They rushed bami's cinder and prevented the enemy team from taking any objectives (because this required channelling and it would be interrupted if you took damage). And because the enemy team never died, they could never buy items. So the tank team got progressively tankier and won through attrition.

It's an awful, unfun strategy. But it's brilliant in it's exploitation of the game's structure.

The team was eventually banned for inting entirely because of the salty enemy team reporting them. Rather than change the game mode's mechanics, Riot punished a group of individuals for innovating a cunning strategy with 0% loss rate.

And that's a tragedy.
And then they got unbanned.
